awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Neuronal Data Assimilation Tools and Models for Understanding Circadian Rhythms
awd_abstract_narration:
Human beings possess an internal timekeeping mechanism known as the circadian clock that aligns physiological processes with the appropriate time of day, for example by stimulating the release of the sleep-promoting hormone melatonin in the evening and the wake-promoting hormone cortisol in the morning. Misalignment of the circadian clock with respect to 24-hour environmental cycles occurs after rapid travel across time zones and leads to symptoms of jet lag including sleep disturbances, digestive problems, and decreased cognitive performance. The circadian clock is highly conserved across animal species, and there are many similarities in the genes and neural circuits involved in the circadian systems of humans and the fruit fly Drosophila. The goal of this project is to obtain a mathematical understanding of the biology underlying jet lag by developing a detailed model of the circadian clock in Drosophila and then systematically analyzing how the clock is disrupted by sudden changes in the timing of the external light-dark cycle. The predictions of the computational model will then be tested in flies through experiments that simulate transmeridian travel. This project will also create new tools for building mathematical models directly from observed data by bringing together techniques from applied mathematics, statistics, and neuroscience. A unique graduate-level course at the intersection of these fields will be developed. Graduate, undergraduate, and community college students will be involved in this research and obtain interdisciplinary training. The undergraduate and community college students will form integrated summer research project teams. Community college students will be recruited to enroll in an undergraduate-level mathematical modeling course at the New Jersey Institute of Technology and will receive mentorship on pursuing four-year STEM degree program opportunities.

This project focuses on the interface between dynamical systems and statistical data analysis in the context of neuronal modeling. The research goal of this project is to develop novel data assimilation methodologies for inferring models of neuronal dynamics directly from time-course data that enable insights into biological mechanisms. Specifically, this project will create new data assimilation tools to identify and parameterize neurophysiological models from voltage traces recorded from the Drosophila circadian (~24-hour) clock network. This research effort will address two major gaps in the mathematical/computational neuroscience field: a scarcity of methods for inferring parameters of unobserved ionic currents from measurements of membrane voltage alone, and a lack of models that link molecular, cellular, and behavioral scales. This will be accomplished by developing a method to design stimulus protocols for use in data assimilation algorithms that optimally unmask the dynamics of unobservable neuronal variables and improve inference of electrophysiological models and parameters. The method will be used to build a model of the Drosophila clock network that links circadian rhythms in gene expression to changes in neuronal activity and behavioral outputs. These models will be used to analyze how the internal circadian oscillator re-entrains following phase shifts in the external light-dark cycle. More generally, this work aims to elucidate fundamental aspects of synchronization and entrainment in oscillatory systems.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed new tools for building mathematical models of the electrical activity of brain cells. The investigators then used these tools to construct models of circadian (~24-hour) clock neurons. These cells are responsible for coordinating daily rhythms in physiology that align an organism's behavior with external environmental rhythms. The sleep/wake cycle is the most obvious circadian rhythm, but there is a wide range of biological processes that exhibit daily oscillations that have profound implications for human health and disease.

Most of what the circadian field knows about clock neurons comes from studies on nocturnal (night-active) rodents. This hinders translation of that knowledge to diurnal (day-active) humans. To address this gap, the investigators collaborated with experimentalists performing electrical recordings from circadian clock neurons in a diurnal rodent species. The investigators built mathematical models using ordinary differential equations (ODEs) that could accurately reproduce the electrical activity of these cells. These models allowed the investigators to characterize the ionic mechanisms underlying a variety of neuronal responses to stimuli. One response of particular interest were cells that exhibited a delay in their return to firing activity when released from an inhibitory input. This delay response was interesting because it had never been observed before in circadian clock neurons of nocturnal animals---in those species the clock neurons always resumed firing activity right away when the inhibitory input was released. Through model simulations and analysis, the investigators predicted that a certain type of transient potassium current was critical for producing the delay response. This prediction was then confirmed experimentally. These results suggest that this potassium current is more prominent in clock neurons of diurnal species. Further model simulations have generated hypotheses about how higher levels of this potassium current help accommodate diurnal animals to their temporal niche.

To build these ODE models the investigators developed a data assimilation (DA) methodology. DA is a framework for optimally combining an imperfect model of a system with noisy measurements from that system to estimate the true system state and model parameters. While DA has been used extensively in the geosciences and for numerical weather prediction, to date it has been applied far less in biology and neuroscience. The two main classes of DA algorithms are variational DA and sequential DA. The investigators compared the performance of these two classes of DA algorithms on synthetic voltage traces where the ground truth model parameters were known, and found that variational DA was able to estimate the parameters of large highly nonlinear neuronal models more accurately than sequential DA. The ability to construct ODE models of neurons directly from voltage traces (current-clamp recordings) is an important step forward for the field, as traditional methods of model fitting require more laborious voltage-clamp recordings and typically involve more hand-tuning of parameters. 

This project also focused on using dynamical systems analysis to gain insight into various situations where a person's circadian clock is not entrained to the 24-h light-dark cycle due to disease or societal reasons. Loss of entrainment can cause a multitude of physiological difficulties associated with misalignment of circadian rhythms, including insomnia, excessive daytime sleepiness, gastrointestinal disturbances, and general malaise. This can occur after travel to different time zones (jet lag), when changing shift work patterns, or if the period of an individual's body clock is too far from the 24-h period of environmental cycles. The investigators analyzed a well-established model of the human circadian pacemaker to address cases where individuals do not entrain, leading to misalignment of their circadian phase. The analysis approach involved bifurcation theory, computation of invariant manifolds, and understanding the dynamics of entrainment maps that measure the phase of the entrained rhythm with respect to the daily onset of lights. For each case, the analysis provided a mathematically justified strategy for how to minimize circadian misalignment.

In addition to these intellectual contributions, this project also had significant broader impacts. The Principal Investigator established the Community College Biomathematical Research Initiation Program (C2BRIP) through a partnership with Essex County College (ECC), a two-year college that is federally designated as a minority-serving institution. In recognition that community college students do not typically have access to as many research opportunities as undergraduates at 4-year universities, the goal of this program is to engage ECC students in summer research projects at NJIT. Over the course of the project, over 20 ECC students worked with the PI on projects involving modeling of infant apnea, tumor growth, SARS-CoV-2 infection, and cardiac arrhythmias. The participants reported that these research experiences bolstered their confidence and made them more likely to pursue 4-year STEM degrees and graduate school.

Overall, the work supported by this project led to 19 peer-reviewed journal publications and 3 doctoral dissertations. This project also provided interdisciplinary training in mathematics and biology to 5 PhD students, 2 Master's students, and several NJIT undergraduate students.
